newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico's TV Azteca says going public. [CORRECTED 22:30 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Mexico's TV Azteca says going public. [CORRECTED 22:30 GMT]

text.p: Mexican television broadcaster TV Azteca said on Monday it planned to launch a global initial public offering worth between $600 and $680 million. (Corrects from "between $600 and $650 million...).
Azteca said it had filed a registration statement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of American Depository Shares (ADS).
"The proposed offering of ADSs, which will be made by prospectus only, is subject, among other things, to market conditions," Azteca said in a statement.

The company said each ADS to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange would represent financial interests in and limited voting rights with respect to one Series A share, one Series D-A shares, and one Series D-L share of TV Azteca. It said the anticipated initial offering price range was $15-$17 per ADS.

Some 93 percent of the global offering will be offered by minority shareholders. Ricardo Salinas Pliego, the company's Chairman, is not participating in the offer as a selling shareholder, the company said.
"The principal purpose of this offering is to provide liquidity to certain minority shareholders and to generate funds to be used by TV Azteca for general corporate purposes," it said.
Bear Stearns and Co. is leading the offering of ADS's outside Mexico, while Banco Inbursa and Grupo Financiero Serfin are co-leading the offer in Mexico.
TV Azteca is the second largest television broadcaster in Mexico. Since its privatization in 1993, the company has steadily taken away market share from media giant Grupo Televisa SA.
